R. C. Punnett conducted experiments on the inheritance of traits in the sweet pea, Lathyrus odoratus. In one experiment, he crossed two different true-breeding sweet pea plant strains, one with erect petals and long pollen, and the other with hooded petals and round pollen. All the offspring (<math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> generation) had erect petals and long pollen (Figure 1).

content.question:
Sweet pea plants have a diploid <math alttext="2 n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>n</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome number of 14.

Which of the following best explains how the sweet pea plants in the parental generation produce <math alttext="F 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> offspring with 14 chromosomes?

choices.label: Meiosis <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> lead to the formation of cells with 14 chromosomes. When two cells combine during fertilization, extra chromosomes are randomly broken down, leading to offspring with 14 chromosomes.

Meiosis <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> lead to the formation of cells with 14 chromosomes. When two cells combine during fertilization, extra chromosomes with recessive traits are broken down, leading to offspring with 14 chromosomes.

Meiosis <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> lead to the formation of cells with 7 chromosomes. During meiosis <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, homologous chromosomes separate. During meiosis <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, sister chromatids separate. Two cells combine during fertilization to produce offspring with 14 chromosomes.

Meiosis <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> lead to the formation of cells with 7 chromosomes. During meiosis <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, sister chromatids separate. During meiosis <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, homologous chromosomes separate. Two cells combine during fertilization to produce offspring with 14 chromosomes.
